Dialogue.NPCText:
You find a young woman in battered armor, her cloak thrown back, watching the Sunreach harbor with haunted resolve. Her voice is low, urgent.

“If you’re here for coin or comfort, turn back. But if you wish to see Sunreach free from Minax’s shadows, then I—Alessa Dawnspire—have work only for the brave.”

Option.text: I want to help Sunreach resist Minax.
Who are you to challenge Minax?
Tell me more about you, Alessa.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Alessa’s eyes brighten—hope flickers in her tired face.

“We fight not for glory, but for tomorrow’s dawn. Minax’s cultists and their corrupt allies poison Sunreach from within. My cell—small, scattered—needs fresh courage.

Will you help us sabotage a shipment of cursed weapons meant for the city guard? If Minax arms them, Sunreach falls for good.”

Option.text: Sabotage the city guard? Isn’t that treason?
This sounds dangerous. Who stands with you?
On second thought, I cannot help.

Dialogue.NPCText:
She draws herself up, not with arrogance but conviction.

“I was once a squire of Trinsic, taught honor and restraint. Here, I fight for something greater—freedom. I lead a handful of rebels, though most know me only as a healer.
My true name is Alessa Dawnspire. If you wish to resist Minax, you’re not alone.”

Option.text: A healer and a rebel—an odd pair.
I’m not interested in your cause.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Her gaze sharpens, wounded but defiant.

“Sunreach is worth saving, if only for those who refuse to bow to Minax. If you will not stand with us, then step aside—for we will not falter.”

Option.text: I spoke too soon. How can I help?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Alessa nods curtly, returning her attention to the distant docks.
“Then may you find the peace we cannot. If you change your mind, seek me again—if Minax’s dogs don’t find me first.”

Alessa manages a faint, rueful smile.
“When evil comes in shadows, healers must learn the sword—or perish with the gentle. I have friends who teach me both.
Jemel the Quick runs messages for us in the slums; Aria Silverhand guides us in secret, risking her own safety. But Captain Rhogar... he hunts us without mercy.”

Option.text: Why does Captain Rhogar hunt you?

Dialogue.NPCText:
She lowers her voice.
“We are few. Jemel the Quick is our eyes and ears in the alleys. Aria Silverhand brings us word from the scholars—and hope, when mine runs low.
But Rhogar Blackwake... he hunts us like beasts. He’ll do anything to crush our cell.”

Alessa hesitates, a flush in her cheeks.
“Aria is... brilliant, brave, and always a step ahead. She risks everything to help us, even while spies hunt her for ancient secrets. I trust her with my life—perhaps more than I should.”

She quickly looks away, then gathers herself.
“Enough. Our cause comes first. Will you help?”

Option.text: I see. Tell me about the sabotage.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Jemel is my oldest friend—quick, clever, and hard to catch. He runs messages, scouts patrols, and knows every shadow in Sunreach.
Without him, we’d be lost. If he trusts you, so do I.”

Option.text: How can I help you now?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Her voice hardens.
“Captain Rhogar controls the docks—and the city’s darker trades. He fears the guard will turn on him if Minax’s cursed weapons succeed. He’d see us dead before he’d lose power.”

Option.text: Then we must act before Rhogar finds you.
This is too dangerous for me.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Alessa’s jaw tightens.
“If justice serves evil, is it still justice? The guards I once admired now serve Minax’s will. Sabotage is not treason—it’s hope, reborn through fire. I’ll ask again: will you help stop these cursed blades?”

Alessa glances over her shoulder, voice dropping to a whisper.

“A ship in the west harbor brings crates of swords—each blade cursed by Minax’s black magic. The guards think them gifts; in truth, they’ll make men into monsters.

I need someone outside my cell. Go to the shadowed warehouse by the salt market. Find the shipment, replace Minax’s talismans with these blessed charms, and slip away unseen. If you’re caught, Rhogar’s men will show no mercy.”

Alessa presses a velvet pouch into your hand.
“Those are holy charms, blessed in secret by Trinsic’s last true paladins. Replace every talisman you find—let no cursed blade remain. When it’s done, return to me, and you’ll have the thanks of every free soul in Sunreach.
May the dawn find you victorious.”

“Minax’s talismans turn men into bloodthirsty beasts. Our charms protect the bearer—and break Minax’s hold on the steel. If you see a blade wrapped in black cord, cut it free and bind one of these instead.”

“Captain Rhogar’s men patrol the harbor. If they catch you, they’ll raise the alarm—if you must, use this smoke bomb. It’ll buy you a few seconds to escape, but no more.”
She passes you a small vial, cold to the touch.
“Aria Silverhand herself brought me the details. If she is deceived, we’re all lost anyway. I trust her—and now I must trust you.”

Option.text: Very well. Give me the charms.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Alessa folds her arms, glancing at the sea.
“Few ask that. I suppose... if you walk into fire beside someone, it helps to know why they burn.”

“What do you wish to know?”

Option.text: Why did you become a paladin?
What does your faith mean to you?
What do you think of Sunreach?

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Trinsic taught me to fight with discipline. But when Minax razed the outskirts, and the order stood idle, I left.”

“Now I follow a path that feels truer—serving the people, not titles. Paladinhood isn’t armor and sermons. It’s sacrifice.”

Option.text: That’s admirable. What keeps you going?

Dialogue.NPCText: “I believed too hard, too young. But disillusionment isn't weakness—it’s clarity. Now, I believe in people. In choices. In dawns we carve ourselves.”

Option.text: So why still call yourself paladin?

Dialogue.NPCText: “Because if I abandon the title entirely, I leave it to those who misuse it. Let the word mean something again—through action, not authority.”

Option.text: I respect that. Tell me about your faith.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“The faces of villagers we’ve saved. The letters Jemel delivers from families reunited. And... Aria.”

Her voice softens briefly. “She reminds me there’s beauty worth protecting.”

Option.text: You care for Aria, don’t you?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Alessa hesitates, then smiles.
“Yes. I do. But my heart must wait. If we lose this fight, nothing else matters.”
She straightens. “Let’s speak of lighter things... for now.”

“I believe faith is a torch. Not to blind, but to guide. I pray to no god blindly, but I hold to the Virtues. Valor. Compassion. Justice.”

“Even if Britannia forgets them, I won’t.”

Option.text: Which virtue do you hold most dear?

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Sacrifice.” She says it without hesitation.

“It’s easy to talk of justice, harder to give everything for others. Minax offers power. I offer pain, hard roads, and hope. And still... people follow.”

“Sunreach is both miracle and monster. Built on trade, ruled by shadow. I love its energy—but loathe its apathy.”
“Darius counts coins. Rhogar counts blades. I count lives.”

She pauses. “Maybe that’s foolish. Maybe not.”

Alessa exhales, laughing softly.
“Personal? Alright.”

“I love river songs from Yew. I once cried over a stray dog that bit me. And I’ve secretly always wanted to see Aerilon’s sky gardens.”
“That personal enough?”

“There’s one about a willow tree waiting for a lost knight. It ends with her becoming the tree herself. Sad, but... peaceful.”
“Jemel used to hum it when we camped outside the city.”

“I hear Aerilon’s sky gardens bloom with petals that catch the moonlight like silver. I just...”
“Want to see something untouched. Unscarred. A place where no blood has been spilled.”

Option.text: Maybe I’ll take you there someday.
